forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
I had a quick look at it.  

It seems to me rather accurate :smile:, though IMHO it uses some terms in a confusing way and uses a "new" acronym VBR for Volume Boot Record instead of the more widely used PBR Partition Boot Record. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png)  

Also, though it seems trivial I find confusing, at least as I personally like to think of the matter, that the first sector on a device is called "bootsector" and that it can contain either a MBR or a PBR.  

I see first sector of any device as the Master Boot Record, which can contain either MBR code (partitioned device) or Partition Boot Record code (unpartitioned device).  

It's just a matter of terms, however. :smile:  

All in all I would say very good work :smile: , though there are still some "grey zones" and missing "spots".  

**Nour El2mar** ,  
if you are game for it, in several days (Mediterranean :smile: ) I could read atttentively your paper and let you know what should/could be changed to better it's accurateness and complete the few missing points.  

Once you'll have seen the proposed additions/changes, you could revise the paper, and post "Release 2.0" in the Tutorial section.   

:smile:   

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: andriusst
forumNotes.content:
Hi Nour El2mar, What can I say, a great article and really accurate. A valuable piece of information and quite thorough too. There are some typos and gramatical errors but I'm really being picky here. Well done.
> I see first sector of any device as the Master Boot Record, which can contain either MBR code (partitioned device) or Partition Boot Record code (unpartitioned device). > jaclaz Sorry jaclaz but I have to disagree with you slightly. To me **Master Boot Record** should fit the following criteria: \* First sector on a disk \* Contains bootstrap code \* Contains partition table And the **Boot Sector** \* First sector of the partition (or disk) \* Contains bootstrap code \* Contains file system description (ie signature, geometry etc) Typically removable media (think floppy disks and optical disks) has only one partition therefore the first sector on a disk is always a Boot Sector. This seems to apply to USB Flash Drives too. That is the main reason we have to "reformat" them with a special tool which actually adds the partition table and make flash drive look hard drive alike to BIOS so it can boot properly. Actually in some cases term "Boot sector" is no longer the most accurate term. For example on FAT32 file system "boot sector" consists of 3 sectors. So name (Volume/Partition) Boot Record used by Nour El2mar would be more accurate. But personally if I see VBR I instantly think of Variable Bit Rate :smile:
